questions.topic: Evolution of UNIX – Bell Labs to modern Linux
questions.question: Where was UNIX originally developed?
questions.answer: UNIX was originally developed at Bell Labs in the late 1960s.

questions.topic: Evolution of UNIX – Bell Labs to modern Linux
questions.question: Why was UNIX considered revolutionary?
questions.answer: Because it was portable, multi-user, and written in the C programming language.

questions.topic: Difference between UNIX, Linux and GNU/Linux
questions.question: What is GNU/Linux?
questions.answer: GNU/Linux is the combination of GNU tools and the Linux kernel forming a complete operating system.

questions.topic: Difference between UNIX, Linux and GNU/Linux
questions.question: Is Linux a UNIX system?
questions.answer: No, Linux is UNIX-like but not original UNIX.

questions.topic: Role of the kernel: process, memory and device management (conceptual)
questions.question: What is the kernel?
questions.answer: The kernel is the core part of an operating system that manages hardware resources.

questions.topic: Role of the kernel: process, memory and device management (conceptual)
questions.question: Name two responsibilities of the kernel.
questions.answer: Process management and memory management.

questions.topic: What is a shell? Bash vs Zsh vs Sh
questions.question: What is a shell?
questions.answer: A shell is a command-line interpreter that allows users to interact with the operating system.

questions.topic: What is a shell? Bash vs Zsh vs Sh
questions.question: Which shell is the default in most Linux systems?
questions.answer: Bash is the default shell in most Linux systems.

questions.topic: Shell vs Terminal vs Console – clearing the confusion
questions.question: What is a terminal?
questions.answer: A terminal is a program that provides access to the shell.

questions.topic: Shell vs Terminal vs Console – clearing the confusion
questions.question: What is a console?
questions.answer: A console is the physical or virtual interface directly connected to the system.

questions.question: Name one core GNU utility.
questions.answer: ls is a core GNU utility.

questions.question: What is the use of cp command?
questions.answer: cp is used to copy files and directories.

questions.answer: Ubuntu is widely used on desktops.

questions.question: Which Linux distribution is famous for servers?
questions.answer: CentOS is famous for servers.

questions.question: What is a desktop Linux used for?
questions.answer: Desktop Linux is used for personal computing like browsing, coding, and office work.

questions.question: What is server Linux mainly used for?
questions.answer: Server Linux is used to host websites, databases and applications.

questions.answer: Ctrl + Alt + T opens the terminal.

questions.answer: pwd means Present Working Directory.

questions.question: What does cd stand for?
questions.answer: cd means Change Directory.

questions.topic: Understanding command structure: command, options, arguments
questions.question: What is a command?
questions.answer: A command is an instruction given to the shell to perform a task.

questions.topic: Understanding command structure: command, options, arguments
questions.question: What is an option?
questions.answer: An option modifies the behavior of a command.

questions.topic: Case sensitivity in Linux file names
questions.question: Are Linux file names case-sensitive?
questions.answer: Yes, Linux file names are case-sensitive.

questions.question: Is file.txt same as File.txt?
questions.answer: No, they are treated as different files.

questions.question: What does man command do?
questions.answer: man displays the manual pages of commands.

questions.question: What is --help used for?
questions.answer: It displays brief usage information about a command.

questions.topic: Understanding environment variables – PATH overview
questions.question: What is PATH?
questions.answer: PATH is an environment variable that stores directories containing executable files.

questions.topic: Understanding environment variables – PATH overview
questions.question: Why is PATH important?
questions.answer: It helps the system locate commands without full paths.

questions.topic: Root user vs normal user – concept and importance
questions.question: Who is the root user?
questions.answer: The root user is the superuser with full system privileges.

questions.question: Why should root access be limited?
questions.answer: Because it can modify or delete critical system files.

questions.answer: It represents the home directory.
